title: Majority of Germans say government’s €54B climate package ‘doesn’t go far enough’: Poll
text:
The poll showed most Germans are pessimistic about humanity's chances of fighting climate change | Michele Tantussi/Getty Images Majority of Germans say government’s €54B climate package ‘doesn’t go far enough’: Poll Most Germans don’t want to pay more for fuel than outlined in the package, however.

A majority of Germans think the government's €54 billion package for combating climate change isn't ambitious enough, according to a poll published Friday.

The package, unveiled last week, includes a range of measures to help the country reach its 2030 emission reduction goals but was criticized by green groups and industry as being too weak.

According to public broadcaster ZDF's Politbarometer survey, 53 percent of Germans agree, saying the package "doesn't go far enough." Just 20 percent consider the package "just right," while 13 percent say it goes too far.

A significant majority of Greens, Social Democrat (SPD) and far-left Linke supporters consider the package insufficient. The SPD is the junior partner to Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democrats (CDU) in Germany's ruling coalition.

Nearly half of pro-business Free Democrat (FDP) voters, 39 percent of CDU supporters and 28 percent of supporters of the far-right, climate-skeptic Alternative for Germany (AfD) also say the measures don't go far enough.

But according to the survey, 63 percent of Germans don't think gasoline and diesel should become more expensive than outlined in the climate package, which foresees a rise of €0.03 per liter from 2021 and between €0.09 and €0.15 per liter from 2026.

The poll also showed most Germans are pessimistic about humanity's chances of fighting climate change. Asked if the world would manage to effectively combat climate change, three quarters of respondents said no.

The Greens, meanwhile, rose by 3 percentage points from earlier in September to shared first place with the CDU, with both parties polling at 27 percent, according to the poll. The SPD dropped two points to 13 percent, slipping into fourth place behind the AfD at 14 percent.

The Greens are also by far the most popular party when it comes to climate change policy. Asked which party best represented their favored policy on climate change, 55 percent of respondents said the Greens. The answers "not sure" and "no party" came in second and third place, respectively, at 14 and 11 percent. The CDU was fourth at 10 percent.

The Politbarometer polled more than 1,300 voters this week. It has a margin of error between 2 and 3 percentage points.
